column4: I'd argue against closure
column5: since some of the standards for judging whether or not we've achieved A.I. - like the Turing Test - are purely psychological. The Eliza Effect is a perfect illustration of why the Turing Test is itself delusional; simply making a mannequin that is good enough to pass for a human being in the dark does not make it a human being. It is thus directly relevant to the definition of A.I. If we didn't already have psychological tests for the definition and routinely discuss them here
column6: I might be more supportive of closure.

column4: Timeouts are very good solution for standard programs
column5: but for adaptively learning programs not: what value do you define the timeout to? At which level? The problem is that by definition you don't know what the AI will face

column4: One method commonly employed in decidedly unintelligent but 24x7 critical systems is the watchdog timer. Basically the system is expected to signal "I'm still alive" within (say) 15 secnds of last time. If it falls into an infinite loop because of circumstances that were not handled correctly
column5: the watchdod s not reset and the timer re-boots the system. A true AI would then subject the circumstances which caused it to hang up to meta-analysis with a view to improving its own programming.

column4: Any learning AI will have an estimator of quality of the applied solution. Simultaneously with trying to solve a problem using *some* algorithm it picked by *some* method
column5: it performs evaluation of progress done by that algorithm. If the algorithm fails to approach the solution in the slightest
column6: it's deemed to be inappropriate and its execution will be discontinued.

column4: Moreover
column5: any AI worth its salt will have a kind of scheduler - estimating cost and value of finding given solution to a problem
column6: and simply deferring too hard problems 'for later'. Even if it doesn't accept 'no solution exists' for an answer
column7: it will defer solving *that* particular paradox until after it's developed philosophical concepts about which no philosophers have dreamed - in which a solution exists. (similarly
column8: tasked with finding roots of y=x^2+1 it first needs to develop the concept of complex numbers.)

column4: Just the obvious thing
column5: each layer of the net is a level of the hierarchy. Neural networks are inherently hierarchical
column6: because every neuron gets input from many "subordinate" neurons in the lower level.

column4: If you have a problem where there are simple subproblems
column5: then it does work to train a short network on the first problem
column6: then add a layer and train the network on the second problem
column8: starting off with training a two-layer edge detector
column10: then...) If you have a hierarchical representation where it's useful to know the lower levels as something besides just a calculation step on the way to knowing the upper levels
column11: then you can expect that sort of system to be successfully built in the wild.

column4: I take your first comment as asking about a different sort of robustness
column5: where I have a functional neural network and
column6: instead of adding more layers that solve different problems
column7: I either add more nodes to the network or add additional layers and attempt to solve the same problem. One expects that the network's performance should only temporarily degrade under this sort of addition
column8: but also that the number of training examples required might grow unnecessarily.

column4: I do mean something other than the learning effect; what I mean is that if you have a robot with
column6: five levels of hierarchical control over its trajectory through space
column7: those levels will each correspond to a different type of thing. (A neuron on the first
column9: and fifth level might look something like the degree of tension in a particular muscle fiber
column11: and a remembered program for how to walk.)

column4: This means that you can execute programs just by adjusting activations on the fifth level while simultaneously being able to inspect the lower-level details. (I might want to calculate where my hand is at a particular point in time
column5: which I can get from investigating the joint angles of my arm and doing a bit of math.)

column4: What I meant by that last sentence is that you can build up the training layer by layer; first you teach the robot how to activate its muscle equivalents
column5: then you teach it how to move them together
column6: then you teach it how to position its limbs
column7: and so on. This means each higher level can basically call the API of the lower levels
column8: rather than learning a policy of what specific muscular tension it needs in every muscle to perform a novel task. This sort of chunking can dramatically lower the required amount of training data.

column4: For your specific example we can encode sentence like this [dissolved barium]~[ice balls on Siberian beaches] where ~ is our causes operator. If we get some sentences that have same elements (barium and Siberian beach) but are connected differently (for example "does not cause") we will label it as false.

column4: Yes
column5: because the expert isn't an expert in assigning accurate probabilities. He is an expert at making decisions. You ask him to do something he didn't train to do. Assigning accurate probabilities isn't relevant to playing well

column4: Yes
column5: that's exactly my point. For humans
column6: comparing options is an easier computational task than assigning accurate probabilities to the options. Accurate probability estimates are sufficient but not necessary for optimal decision making. Demanding that the expert perform his comparisons on the real number line handicaps him. So demanding the same of our AI systems might be a handicap as well.

column4: To be clear
column5: it is a handicap when we force the mappings of A and B to the real number line to be made *independently*. That's why in my illustration I have half the experts estimate A and the other half estimate B without getting to talk to each other. Perhaps it might make sense to think of a "comparison" as a joint-estimate-vector with an uncertainty covariance matrix U; the handicap can be interpreted as restrictions on U.

column6: and it was convincing enough to provoke interesting philosophical discussions.

column5: I mean that on the right of the tree Min chooses 0 instead of 2 left and right it chooses -1 instead of 0. Then we multiply both with 0.5 and get the sum of -0.5. Which is the value what Min delivers to Max. This models that Min chooses the minimal values (the leafs) and then has a chance of 50 % to choose between the two possible moves with the value 0 and -1 respectively.

column5: you are trying to break the query into components which are (sort-of) basis vectors in information space (the cube). One way is to search the tokens from the query string through the entire hierarchies (use idea of closeness/similarity to find the appropriate attribute). Another could be by converting the query string into a vector (in spaCy) and then taking the inner product with vectors from within the cube; use similarity to find closeness with concepts/axis. column4: There's so many different factors involved in the "AI in a box experiment" that I think it is not really possible to sensibly answer such a question. Basically we have to answer (a) can we build an AGI that is scary enough to *want* to put into a box?
column5: (b) can we build the box in such a manner that the AGI would rather prefer to convince a human being than simply brute-force its way out of the box? and (c) is breaking out of the box something an AGI actually want? IMHO
column6: the only way to know how the experiment would work IRL is to actually do the experiment IRL.

column1: 2. When you have a large pretrained network and you want to keep the architecture unchanged and you want to use it to work with a smaller amount of data - I've empirically found that with little data you can apply strong L2 regularization with v. good effects (to fc layers - not to conv layers). The same doesn't apply to dropout. Keeping less than 0.5 neurons may result in v. unstable training.

You can use some heuristics to start with a network whose weights are not completely random. It is called transfer learning. But it's hard to do because it implies you knowing the values somehow (usually
column5: through previous learning stages). You also cannot just set some specific values and expect others to remain unchanged. As you adjust weights to get some actions to -inf

column7: which will most likely disturb training. Once you start optimizing the network
column9: backprop will just optimize the weights and set everything back.

column4: By setting an end reward
column5: you just motivate the agent to finish the task (since he gets the best reward out of finishing it). You still need the negative rewards
column7: to make him avoid wasting resources. With penalties and an end-game reward
column8: you get the best of both worlds.

column1: I'd also point out that the general idea of playing against versions of yourself has a long history in the literature around learning to play games. One of the very earliest real success stories in AI was Arthur Samuel's checkers program in 1959. He trained a program to play the game at the level of a very strong human by having it play games against itself

column1: Qualia: The Knowledge Argument:

The knowledge argument aims to establish that conscious experience involves non-physical properties. It rests on the idea that someone who has complete physical knowledge about another conscious being might yet lack knowledge about how it feels to have the experiences of that being. It is one of the most discussed arguments against physicalism.

column5: certainly good enough for this field. Layers in real neocortex differ from most neural networks in that they are massively recurrent
column6: consist of simultaneously active feed-forward and feed-back
column7: and very dependent on recent history and overall state. And that's just in one visual area (like V1). Some artificial networks impart some of these features
column8: others mimic them with other more computationally-friendly mechanisms.

column4: PS- please don't misinterpret intent as to diminish your excellent answer. Quite the opposite!  It's *because* the answer has such merit that I wanted to take the time to comment on a related subject that is a preoccupation of mine.
@JadenTravnik's answer is good
column5: also see my comment there. The difference between the reference here and that answer is this citation seems to be implying that there is a feed-forward structure in a *single column* in neocortex (since that's the picture represented here). This is certainly false
column6: though works as a model sometimes. Although there is evidence for some feed-forward processing in a column
column7: there is also a ton of recurrence and feedback. The feed-forward structure makes more sense between cortical areas (this is what the answer below addresses).

column4: The terminology of "layer" has a different meaning in the two contexts as well. When biologists talk about cortical "layers" they mean anatomical layers
column5: not functional neural network-style layers. Cells within one layer are highly interconnected with each other
column6: as well as to a lesser extent with cells of all of the other layers. Some of the connectivity is in this answer to a different question at biology.se: https://biology.stackexchange.com/questions/57495/cortical-projections-from-layers-2-3-back-to-4/57519#57519

the depth of the  feature map n+1 is equal to the numbers of kernels you used in the feature map n. so if you just use 1 kernel the depth of the next feature map is 1. - each feature map has its own kernel - this is one of the main advantages of the CNN over the full connected NN: there are much less parameters to fit.

column5: there is some misconception about this "inner drive". A child isn't curious for the sake of curiosity. column4: True consciousness can only arise when playing an infinite game like the game of life. Is there any justification for this statement?

column5: if Aiwyn's a finite player (i.e. it's playing a finite game) then that would mean that it has a finite objective (e.g. to destroy the One Ring by throwing it in the Cracks of Doom). To achieve this goal it might need to pass off as human (or hobbit
column7: whatever). That means that it would need to pass the Turing Test. However
column8: does that make it conscious? No. Passing off as being conscious doesn't imply actually being conscious.

column4: I conjecture that it's impossible for Aiwyn to be conscious if it's only playing a finite game because then it would have nothing to look forward to after the game is over. It wouldn't be "conscious" in the sense that you and I are conscious. For example
column5: suppose your goal in life is to raise kids until they can take care of themselves. Once you've achieved your goal
column6: will you just stop living? Will you have nothing else to do? No. Your mind will make new desires and set new goals because your mind is playing an infinite game.

column4: I might look at stinginess as the direct application of minimax in non-iterated  dilemma.  The agent takes the pessimistic strategy
column6: because the rational approach is to minimize harm in a worst-case scenario.  This in itself is not evil
column7: because there is no communication between the competing agents.  This is distinct from iterated dilemma
column8: where an agent can communicate it's superrationality by cooperating on the first iteration (golden rule) and second iteration
column9: even with a previous betrayal by the competing agent (turn the other cheek).

column4: In iterated Dilemma
column5: if the competing agent persists in betrayal despite the cooperative action of the superrational agent
column6: which constitutes communication of the agent's superrationality
column7: the betrayal becomes non-rational.  (i.e. the rational agent is now ahead
column8: and can risk cooperation without the risk of being worse off in aggregate than the competitor.)  At this point the betraying agent is hampering the maximization of benefit.  Thus
column10: a strategy of persistent betrayal regardless of circumstance may be regarded as evil.  The evil agent never cooperates.

column4: It seems like you might want to add additional layering for score instead of just the immediate I moved one degree I get a point. Perhaps a moving window that calculates total degrees moved over the last TBD-seconds. I would probably give that more weight than near-term score. I would think that should help prevent weaving and circling. Which might beg the question of why keep a near-term score at all but I would keep the near-term score because I suspect it will help get around obstacles.
You also might need to take into account 'obstacles' movement. That includes speed and direction. Perhaps your cars are circling because they are trying to avoid other cars. However

column4: Hi @neil I'm back propagating after every move
column5: NN plays both sides. I adjust the weights and eligibility traces for the current state using the previous states values according to https://web.archive.org/web/20100625030049/http://www.cse.unr.edu/robotics/bekris/cs482_f09/sites/cse.unr.edu.robotics.bekris.cs482_f09/files/backgammon.pdf At the terminal state I change 'y1' in the above equations to be either `0` for a draw or `+-1` for win/lose. I use a 2-ply search to find the best move to make based upon the average value of all the opponents possible response move.

The generator is trained in a (sorta) supervised fashion because there is actually a label associated with the x' it generates (whether the discriminator could detect that it was a counterfeit or not).  Unsupervised methods are used when there are no labels and one wants to understand how their data either by clustering or finding a good distance function. column4: @DukeZhou This is used in theoretical computer science. When you can't solve a problem efficiently
column5: often instead you generate a random number and use that number to cheat in some way that allows you to solve the problem efficiently. However
column6: because of the cheat it's not necessarily correct. What you do then is write a formula for the probability of being wrong
column7: run the program a bunch of times
column8: and get a small error term by aggregating all of the results.

column4: For example
column5: checking if two numbers are equal is hard. It requires looking at every single digit
column6: and some numbers have a huge number of digits. Instead
column7: I can generate a random prime with 1000 digits and check if a = b mod p. Calculating a mod p and b mod p can be done really easily
column8: and then to check the comparison I only have to compare 1000 digit numbers
column9: which is a constant independent of a and b. If a and b are actually equal
column10: then they're equal mod p too
column11: but sometimes I'll get the answer wrong by accident because of the algebraic relationship between a and b.

column4: However
column5: I can do this many times with different randomly generated prime numbers. I say that a != b if I found a prime such that a != b mod p. This is guaranteed to be correct
column6: when I output it. When I don't find a disproof
column7: I guess that a = b. This will sometimes be wrong. However
column8: it turns out that the rate at which the error goes to 0 as the number of primes I guess increases is exceptionally fast.

column5: because it cuts out after certain number of actions. Eventually the Q-table will forget the large optimistic starting values due to the fixed learning rate. But really this is the same as behaving randomly to start with (e.g. for 100 steps) then behaving closer to optimally later. You still need some exploration after the exploration function is exhausted

column5: unless you select for diversity (novelty search). Convergence on a local optimum is a common problem with generic algorithms. Your may try to mitigate this by enlarging the population size and/or increasing mutation rate (crossover is not considered to be an explorative operator).
